Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI: Constraining the mechanisms of melt transport, storage, and crustal contamination from temporal geochemical variations in monogenetic vents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Monogenetic vents are relatively small volcanoes that are active for a single eruption over a period of a few months to a few years, in contrast to more typical volcanoes that are gradually built up over many different eruptions and which are typically intermittently active for 10s of thousands of years or longer. Monogenetic vents often occur in clusters, and are a common type of volcanism in many tectonic settings. Several monogenetic vent fields occur in or near high-population-density areas, including Auckland, New Zealand and Mexico City, Mexico. Therefore, monogenetic vents represent a significant volcanic hazard. Previous studies have shown that the compositions of the ash and lava erupted from a monogenetic vent during the course of an eruption often varies systematically over time. The cause of this variability is not clear, but it most likely reflects either processes involved in melt generation and extraction from the mantle, or melt storage in the continental crust and melt/crust interaction prior to eruption. A better understanding of the cause(s) of the chemical variations observed in monogenetic vent eruptions would provide scientists with a better understanding of the plumbing system that feeds these volcanoes. This in turn will allow better prediction of the precursor signals that may signal an impending eruption.

This study will combine numerical modeling of melt transport and storage processes with detailed geochemical analyses of material erupted from selected monogenetic vent eruptive sequences to better constrain the processes of melt generation, ascent, and storage that precede the eruption of monogenetic vents. Different hypothesized mechanisms for generating chemical variations in monogenetic vent sequences (e.g., reactive melt transport in the mantle or progressive draining of magma sills that are emplaced in the shallow crust prior to eruption) will produce different temporal chemical variations. We will compare model predictions with observations to constrain the likely origin of these variations, and then use the observed variations to extract information on important variables related to melt generation, transport, and storage such as the size of chemical heterogeneities in the mantle source region, the volume and geometry of magma storage chambers in the crust, and the time interval between melt injection into the crust and subsequent eruption of this stored magma. This information can be used in future studies to predict the most likely signals that may indicate an impending eruption (e.g., upward ground deformation due to magma injection) as well as the likely time lag between these signals and an actual eruption. The proposed study with therefore both improve our overall understanding of a geologically important and widespread style of continental volcanism, and improve our ability to evaluate and plan for the risks inherent in possible future monogenetic vent eruptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The goal of this project was to examine the cause of compositional variations observed during the course of volcanic eruption of “monogenetic vent volcanoes”, small volcanoes that typically erupt only once but that often occur in clusters or fields. Previous studies had suggested that these compositional variations could reflect melt generation and extraction processes occurring in the mantle, such as mixing of melts generated from different components in the mantle. Alternatively, the variations could reflect assimilation of continental crust during ponding in the crust prior to eruption, and mixing of contaminated and non-contaminated melts at the time of eruption. Distinguishing between these two hypotheses is important both for understanding the behavior of monogenetic vent volcanoes and their plumbing systems (with implications for volcanic risk assessment and mitigation) and because compositional variations in volcanic rocks are commonly used to infer information about the composition and evolution of the mantle and how this is related to tectonic processes such as plate subduction of rifting. Proper interpretation of the “mantle signals” in volcanic products requires an understanding of both melt generation and extraction processes and magma storage and evolution in the crust.

To address these goals, this project took a novel approach that focused on examining the “crystal cargo”, or crystal phases that were transported to the surface by the erupting magma at a well-characterized volcanic sequence in eastern California, the “Papoose Canyon” sequence. The compositions of the mineral phases revealed that the crystals had grown from earlier magmas that had ponded within the continental crust and cooled and partially crystallized prior to eruption. These “evolved” magmas then mixed with hotter, more primitive magmas at the same time that the eruption occurred, suggesting that the arrival of this second pulse of magma  is what triggered the volcanic eruption. This finding is significant because it suggests that, contrary to many previous suggestions, magmas that fed volcanic eruptions within this volcanic field had a protracted history of storage within the continental crust prior to eruption. 

This project also developed numerical modeling methods to simulate the transport of magma through partially-molten mantle. The results showed that in media with variable porosity, magma can ascend in pulses that resemble “vortices” similar to smoke rings that act to prevent chemical signatures associate with discrete pulses from becoming “blurred out” as they ascend. This result contradicts previous, simpler models of reactive melt transport. Finally, we also modeled the formation of magma “sills” or areas of magma storage within the crust, and subsequent draining of these sill in response to arrival of a second magma pulse. Both types of models make specific predictions about how the compositions of erupted magmas should change over time, allowing comparison with observations from real volcanoes. We are currently integrating the modeling results with observations from Papoose Canyon and other volcanic vents to place better constraints on the depths of magma storage prior to erption, the volume of stored melt, and the time interval between initial magma injection and subsequent eruption. All of these variables are important for understanding how monogenetic vent volcanoes function and for prediction both the timing and intensity of future eruptions. 

Broader Impacts

Our results show that magmas erupted at many monogenetic vent volcanoes contain an admixture of an evolved melt that ponded and fractionated within the crust for an extended period prior to eruption. Eruption in many cases may be triggered by the arrival of a second, hotter and  more primitive melt into the crust. This suggests that in monogenetic vent fields, geophysical identification of magma emplacement within the crust (e.g., through seismicity related to magma injection or through ground deformation measurements) may provide warning indicators of approaching eruptions with significant lead time. Geophysical monitoring of high-risk metropolitan areas located within or adjacent to monogenetic vent fields may therefore be useful for providing an “early warning” of impending eruptions.

In addition, many other types of geologic processes involve the reactive transport of a fluid through a solid medium with variable porosity, including groundwater transport of contaminant plumes through porous aquifers. The numerical models developed to examine the reactive transport of magma through the mantle can easily be modified to examine a wide range of other problems of societal relevance. This project thus contributed to the development of “intellectual infrastructure” in the form of software code that is beneficial to society.
